body:
Thanks for the pointer.
Of course it was super obvious, the system was using the apt python package and not the pip one.
Now it works fine for me !
By adding profile `osx-x86_64-gpu` in `core/pom.xml`, with a new sub module under `native`, I think it should not be hard to support gpu on osx. Are you interested in contributing this support?

This maybe helpful.
http://mxnet.io/how_to/new_op.html
If it is possible, please push a scala_2.11 jar to the maven central repository. Thanks!
@howard0su

It should be changed to w += -lr * dfdx / ( sqrt(delta)+eps ). No need for a new parameter.
Would you like to propose a fix?
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/image-classification

@kevinthesun 
Its working for me. Probably browser version issue?
Maybe but I've tried it at both home and work by using Chrome and Firefox.
Sorry for not updating this issue. Both training and predicting using the ImageRecord iterators solved my problem.

@skrish13 Sorry for the late reply, since I couldn't figure out how to solve my problem I changed the direction of my project. I have no idea about your error, I have never came up with it before. If I hadn't abandoned this script so long ago, I would definitely try to help you. Sorry again for that.
Thank you very much for your interest anyway.
It's working for me on chrome but not safari or firefox.
Also when I build it locally, it works fine for chrome, safari and firefox.

You cannot do dot xy T you need to do dot yT xT

We have gradient check see testoperator

Minjie Wang <notifications@github.com>于2017年1月2日 周一下午6:31写道：

> *@jermainewang* commented on this pull request.

>
>
>

>
>

> In src/operator/tensor/matrix_op-inl.h
> <https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/4498>:
>
>
> > @@ -376,8 +399,19 @@ void DotBackward_(const nnvm::NodeAttrs& attrs,
>
>      mshadow::Tensor<xpu, 2, real_t> mrhs_data = inputs[2].get<xpu, 2, real_t>(s);
>
>      mshadow::Tensor<xpu, 2, real_t> mlhs_grad = outputs[0].get<xpu, 2, real_t>(s);
>
>      mshadow::Tensor<xpu, 2, real_t> mrhs_grad = outputs[1].get<xpu, 2, real_t>(s);
>
> -    ASSIGN_DISPATCH(mrhs_grad, req[1], dot(mlhs_data.T(), mout_grad));
>
> -    ASSIGN_DISPATCH(mlhs_grad, req[0], dot(mout_grad, mrhs_data.T()));
>
> +    if (param.transpose_a && param.transpose_b) {
>
>
>
> Hmm... sorry I think I made some mistakes. We know that:
>
>
> z = dot(x, y)
>
> dx = dot(dz, y.T)
>
> dy = dot(x.T, dz)
>
>
>
> Then, we should have:
>
>
> z1 = dot(x.T, y)
>
> dx = dot(dz1, y).T
>
> dy = dot(x, dz1)
>
>
>
> z2 = dot(x, y.T)
>
> dx = dot(dz2, y)
>
> dy = dot(x.T, dz2).T
>
>
>
> z3 = dot(x.T, y.T)
>
> dx = dot(dz3, y).T
>
> dy = dot(x, dz3).T
>
>
>
> Basically, I miss the T here. Does this make sense to you?
>
>
> Question: how to do dot(x, y).T in one mshadow call? Is it equal to one
> blas call or one blas call + one physical transpose?
>
>
>

This change will impact all the current code and cause the parallel execution/dispatching doesn't happen since most of the current code will have 0 as priority.

I suggest to thinking about other direction to consider GPU memory as a resource. Maybe fun to look at how nnvm pass can help this.

I tried using model.score inside my custom callback to calculate the train and the test accuracy scores... unfortunately this lead to an infinite fit process cause using the train iterator inside the callback. ... Using a separate iterator does not work well - not sure why. No easy solution to measure these scores :(  I could use model-fit, i.e in between fit operation, measuring the train score, but it looks a bit overkill, and the measure will be at low freq... 

So if you have any better suggestion :)

Sphinx 1.5.1 will update JQuery to 3.1.0, while Bootstrap requires JQuery 1.9.1 to 3.0.0. 
I fixed this issue by using JQuery version 1.11.1, which is the version for current website.
Fixed in PR https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/4501

    Example description.
    >>> code
    >>> code
Still issue there. JQuery 1.11.1 is not generated by sphinx 1.5.1
Fixed in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/4503

@howard0su , it won't affect the parallelism. It will only affect the dispatch order of parallel operators. If two operators could be run in parallel, they will still be run in parallel.

NNVM pass could help the symbolic part since we have the whole graph, but for imperative way like minpy, we only have segments and graph may change during running. I haven't come up with a good idea of how to utilize NNVM pass for these scenarios. It will definitely be one of the future direction of minpy. Maybe you have more thoughts on this?
data needs to be a list of ndarrays. You should use [outG]

thank you it works just fine!
but still another question. If I called for backward function like this.

```
diffD = modD.get_input_grads()
modG.backward(diffD)
```

diffD is the diff passing through from Discriminator, the error occurred like this.

MXNetError: [14:15:45] D:\Program Files (x86)\Jenkins\workspace\mxnet\mxnet\src\executor\graph_executor.cc:44: Check failed: i < head_grads.size() && !head_grads[i].is_none() Because the last operator is not Loss function, head_gradient is required in calling backward.

Is it due to that the group symbol is my last operator?
what should I do to make it work? I want the diff pass through the last tanh activative function of generator, and only to record the changing of encoder sequence output.
I think it's the same problem. Make sure diffD matches modG's output

According to the tutorial of official website , can be configured successfully,  tutorial :http://mxnet.io/how_to/multi_devices.html, 
Of course，piiswrong mean  was right so. This is very simple，maybe  will be some problems of ssh，If you are not familiar with SSH。

Yes, things like this can do.
```
diff_null = mx.nd.zeros((1,512,1,1), ctx=ctx)
modG.backward([diffD[0],diff_null])
```

But still both the grouped symbols should have a head_gradients. I cannot find some way to blind one of them to prevent extra computation. And still I think Group symbol can be misleading somehow...

Thanks for helping! You're so kind and helpful. MXnet is my favorite!
seems like this #4335
Can we implement this with FIFO queue? since the operation on priority queue could be slower than a fifo queue.
I'll do it this weekend.

Hi all, my current gut feeling is that this piece of functionality may be best provided as a standalone project, under a compatible and permissive license (most likely apache), so as to benefit other frameworks also.

It would seem that outside of TF Serving, there's not a lot out there. Deep Detect looks interesting @beniz, however it appears to be under the GPL license - can you please confirm?

### Lambda / OpenWhisk
Lambda would almost certainly be a great option if it had GPU support, and Amazon will almost certainly provide this in the near future, whether via a different class of lambda or via their new elastic GPU offering (which may be slightly less suited here than the prior). This if of course not an open source solution, and as such may not be the ideal. This had me thinking about other options for implementing a simple, server-less method for hosting inference models, and I think [OpenWhisk](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk) may suit here.

### GPU Compatibility 
I can't find validation that it works on GPUs, however their generic action invocation appears to run an arbitrary binary via [Alpine Linux](https://alpinelinux.org/), which I've used with cuda in the past with some success. I'll spin up an OpenWhisk VM on my GPU box and report back as to whether or not GPUs are accessible, however it's not immediately obvious to me why it shouldn't be.

### Simplification
From there, I think making use of the amalgamation script/s within Mxnet  to provide a simple 'runnable' object may be a good approach to providing a simple deployment process to users. This will obviously need performance testing.

### Mxnet Integration
I think this could prove to be a powerful tool for many ML frameworks, with MxNet serving as the foundation in places. Perhaps this would best be its own project/repository, mirrored within and closely integrating with Mxnet? Thoughts on this are much appreciated.

Please let me know your thoughts, and once I've validated some of the moving pieces, particuarly GPU support on OpenWhisk, I'll knock together a design proposal for further discussion.
DD is under LGPL, please see https://github.com/beniz/deepdetect/blob/master/COPYING.

I reread the code in engine and dmlc ConcurrentBlockingQueue.

The root cause is that ConcurrentQueue is using std::push_heap to insert op into the list. unfortunately, heap sort is not a stable sort algorithm. So it is not strict FIFO when priority is same (zero in most cases.)

Personally, I don't suggest to merge this fix. instead, we should reimplement ConcurrentBlockingQueue with a stable implementation of PriorityQueue.

Also, when I investigate why threaded engine is slow on CPU. ConcurrentBlockingQueue also introduces contention during worker threads. I am also looking at do some change in this class. @piiswrong

I had some offline discussion with @piiswrong 

You are right. my previous comments are not correct.

The concern for the current solution is we overload priority parameter. One possible solution can be:
1. maintain a order count. and assign this count to the newly pushed operation. and order + priority >> 16 as a priority. (need a smart way to handle order overflow)
2. Always prioritize DeleteVariable op so that we can free memory.
Please merge if this is ok. The change at least double the performance in single GPU.
